intro: Gynerium argenteum var. strictum, commonly known as silverleaf goldenrod, is a perennial herb native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and narrow, silver-gray leaves that are covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellow flowers in panicles during the summer months, which attract various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers moist, well-drained soils. This species is often found in wetlands, streambanks, and other moist habitats.
